newsitem.title: USA: UAL to use cash, financing to pay for jets.
newsitem.headline: UAL to use cash, financing to pay for jets.

text.p: UAL Corp, parent of United Airlines, said Friday it will purchase 51 new jets valued at $4.4 billion with a combination of cash from operations and financing arranged at the time of delivery.
On August 22, United announced it ordered 27 new wide body aircraft from Boeing Co and 24 narrow-body A319 aircraft from Airbus Industrie.

Based on the manufacturers' list prices, the value of the Boeing order would be $3.5 billion and the Airbus order would be $900 million. But company spokesman Joseph Hopkins reiterated that United paid less than list price.
He declined to give the exact amount paid for the planes.

On August 15, United said it was ordering $2.5 billion in planes from Boeing and was looking to buy about $600 million worth of narrow body planes from Boeing or Airbus. United did not specify the number of planes to be purchased at that time.
Hopkins said United expects to take delivery of all its new planes by the year 2002.
The delivery schedule calls for four A319 planes from Airbus to be delivered in 1997, 15 in 1998 and the others in subsequent years.
Of the 19 new 747s ordered from Boeing, two 747-400 planes will be delivered in 1996, six in 1997 and four in 1998, with the rest to be delivered later.
The schedule for the new order of two 777 planes from Boeing, combined with 34 previously ordered, include eight being delivered in 1996, 14 in 1997 and four in 1998.
Six new 757 jets from Boeing, combined with previous orders, will be delivered starting with four this year, two in 1997 and three in 1998.
United has said it is buying the new planes to replace older models in an effort to upgrade its fleet without expanding capacity beyond demand.
Hopkins said United's plans for 1996 call for eight 737-200s, six DC10-10s made by McDonnell Douglas Corp and three 747-100s to be retired.
In 1997, United plans to retire eight 737-200s, four DC10-10s, four DC-30s and six 747-100s. In 1998, it will retire 29 737-200s, six DC10-10s, four 747-100s and six 747-200s.
Hopkins said United normally seeks a buyer for its retired planes.
